<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>This week, for the first time in what felt like a year (okay, it was a year), I took a walk in New York City without wearing a mask.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It was all going great until I saw a woman walking her dog approach me. She was wearing a mask, and my body instinctively moved to cross to the other side of the street to give her space. It made me realize that we’ve been living the past year in fear of other humans, which is pretty sad.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Pandemic-era habits die hard, but I’m confident we can once again re-wire our brains to view other people not as biological vectors for disease, but as...people, just with germs. Here's to hoping this summer, we’ll learn to come together as quickly as we learned to distance.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>

</tr>

</p>
</td>

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With... Barbara Corcoran
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/14/icebreakers-withbarbara-corcoran-84ae" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Barbara Corcoran " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MDcxL2JhcmJhcmFfY29yY29yYW4uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Courtesy of Barbara Corcoran</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">You will learn more about succeeding in business in a 30-minute conversation with Barbara Corcoran than in most college courses. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We’d know, we did ’em both. The real estate mogul, <em>Shark Tank</em> mainstay, and host of the podcast <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/business-unusual-with-barbara-corcoran/id1378685290?mt=2" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Business Unusual</em></a><em> </em>answered our Icebreaker questions with the same empathetic-but-no-BS attitude she displays on TV. Check out our interview below. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What is the most frequent reason you’re “out” on a company on </strong><strong><em>Shark Tank</em></strong><strong>?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">A guy who doesn’t make eye contact with me or the women on the set. It happens more than you think. They want a guy as a partner and that’s where it ends—and you can tell right away when they stand on that set. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Are they just intimidated? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Yes, but even when they’re not making eye contact because they’re intimidated I’m out right away. And I’m out for a good reason: because building a business takes a lot of on-the-spot pressure, fast-on-your-feet kind of thinking. You have to be able to perform under pressure. And I see right away this person is going to fold under pressure. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What is your secret skill?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I’m a helluva good tarot card reader. And I’ve lived long enough to see that most of what I’ve predicted has proved out. I’ve gotten very confident in my later years. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Wait—how did you get into tarot cards? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Out of need, thinking on my feet. I went to a real estate conference at a young age and it was the first time I rented a booth, trying to hustle business straight from other brokers. Anyway, when I got to the conference there was nothing at the booth—I was mortified. So my associate and I ran out and bought tarot cards, and I started reading. And after about 40 minutes, there was a line a mile long for the tarot cards. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It was the best thing I ever thought of to promote business. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If you could do something that you don’t do because it’s bad for you, but you could do it without any repercussions—what would you do?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I would throw my phone off the Brooklyn Bridge and never read another text. Free myself. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You should do that.</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">You know, I hate the word “should,” but I am going to do that now. What you just said. I’m going to do that this summer. I go to the beach, and I’m always on my phone when I never used to be. I had no TV, no radio, no phone, and I don’t think I’ve known that degree of relaxation probably for the last 15 years. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Yeah, I’m going to do that...I’m going to leave my phone in Manhattan. See how I survive. I will probably feel young again and relaxed. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There’s <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/14/icebreakers-withbarbara-corcoran?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">so much more of the interview at this link</a>. </p>

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
How to Leave a Company Gracefully
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/14/make-work-leave-company-gracefully" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reader-submitted questions</a> about work in 2021. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Q: "I’m struggling with the possibility of leaving my company of almost 2.5 years. I’ve never felt supported or appreciated by management, and I don’t particularly like my colleagues. Do you have advice on how to have that conversation gracefully?"—Ashley</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>A: </strong>Hi Ashley, I’m sorry that your experience at work has turned into a sour one. Let's talk next steps. You can have the notice conversation gracefully by letting your manager know as directly as possible (in person or over videochat) before submitting your resignation notice. You don't have to share with your manager why you’ve decided to leave, but be prepared to be asked the question by HR during your exit interview. End the news by saying that you are grateful for the experience and have learned skills that you will carry throughout your professional career.  </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Don't believe me? Check out what another Sunday Edition reader submitted in response to a previous Make It Work post. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>"Hi, Kate. I just read your response to the person looking at changing jobs. I don’t disagree with what you wrote, but my experiences also include “how” I quit and change jobs. Even with the bad environments, I still left with good feelings, graciously, lots of warnings, and smooth transitions. Any scorched-earth actions will follow a person to future jobs. I still get calls and good references from past employers."—</em>Darren Z.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Oh! And please please give your employer a two-week notice, meaning 10 full business days, at minimum. Notices <em>longer</em> than two weeks is an awesome look on you, too (side note: I would recommend a minimum of three weeks if you’re at the Director level or higher). </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Something bothering you at work? <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Kate for advice here</a>.</em></p>

<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Revenge of the Retail Traders
</h1>
<img alt="NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MAY 23:  An exterior view of Hertz Car Rental durin..." style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MDc4L2RhaWx5X2xpZmVfaW5fbmV3X3lvcmtfY2kuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Cindy Ord/Getty Images</em>
</small>
</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Before there was GameStop, there was Hertz.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Last June, a gang of Robinhood traders helped push the rental car’s stock up nearly 600% in less than a week, which was a curious thing to do considering the company had just filed for bankruptcy, was weighed down by nearly $19 billion in debt, and had roughly 700,000 cars parked with no one to drive them. Things were looking pretty bleak. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The Hertz traders were ridiculed as “<a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2020-06-12/if-you-want-hertz-have-some-hertz?sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nuts</a>,” emblematic of the casino-type stock market that had emerged when the coronavirus wiped calendars clean. And they may very well have been nuts.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">But they were vindicated</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This week, Hertz <a href="https://news.yahoo.com/hertz-shareholders-line-8-recovery-115253916.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reached a deal</a> with a couple private equity firms to take it out of bankruptcy. That deal is a stunning victory for shareholders.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It values the company at about $7 billion, and equity holders will receive up to $8/share. During the trading frenzy last June, Hertz topped out at $6.25 a share, which means if you were the fool who bought Hertz at its peak, you’d still have been undervaluing the company.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This arrangement is...highly unusual. Writing in Vanity Fair last June, former Wall Street banker William Cohan <a href="https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2020/06/bankrupt-hertz-is-a-pandemic-zombie?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">explained</a> what happens in typical corporate restructuring cases:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>“What happens 99.9% of the time is that existing shareholders get wiped out and the creditors, most of which won’t get their money back, divide up what’s left of the carcass.”</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>He predicted “there will be no recovery for the shareholders. As in zero.”</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">At the time, most analysts agreed with Cohan. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But very few predicted how Hertz’s fortunes would change as the economy rocketed out of the pandemic. Blocked from traveling to many other countries, Americans are turning to road trips for summer 2021 vacations. Used cars accounted for more than a third of consumer price increases last month. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Hertz has also gotten a little lucky—yes, we’re talking about the chip shortage. Car manufacturers have had to slow production of <em>new </em>cars for lack of semiconductors, meaning rental car companies with fleets of used cars are in the right place at the right time.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">A full recovery for Hertz <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-12/once-doomed-hertz-rebounded-so-much-even-redditors-were-right?sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">isn’t a slam dunk</a>, Bloomberg writes. Revenue hasn’t returned to pre-pandemic levels and the chip shortage, while now an advantage, could turn into a liability if Hertz is forced to keep buying used cars, which are expensive and could degrade the quality of its fleet.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line: </strong>Throughout this rollercoaster of a pandemic-era stock market, it’s nearly impossible to tell which investors are smart, which ones are dumb, and which are just plain lucky. </p>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the newsletter section that highlights the most interesting home listings that even Davina from <em>Selling Sunset </em>could sell. Meme Battle
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome back to Morning Brew's Meme Battle, where we crown a single memelord every Sunday.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Today's memelord: </strong>Alex from Alexandria, VA, with this new spin on a classic.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MDg0L3Vub19jYXJkX21lbWUuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>This week's challenge: </strong>You can find the <a href="https://imgflip.com/memegenerator/Tuxedo-Winnie-The-Pooh?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new meme template here</a> for next Sunday. Once you're done making your meme, <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/JfSpw1CH?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">submit it at this link</a>. We'll pick a new memelord in next week's Sunday Edition and provide you with another meme template to meme-ify. </p>

#353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eThis week, for the first time in what felt like a year (okay, it was a year), I took a walk in New York City without wearing a mask.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt was all going great until I saw a woman walking her dog approach me. She was wearing a mask, and my body instinctively moved to cross to the other side of the street to give her space. It made me realize that we’ve been living the past year in fear of other humans, which is pretty sad.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003ePandemic-era habits die hard, but I’m confident we can once again re-wire our brains to view other people not as biological vectors for disease, but as...people, just with germs. Here's to hoping this summer, we’ll learn to come together as quickly as we learned to distance.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; Barbara Corcoran\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/14/icebreakers-withbarbara-corcoran-84ae\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Barbara Corcoran \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MDcxL2JhcmJhcmFfY29yY29yYW4uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eCourtesy of Barbara Corcoran\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYou will learn more about succeeding in business in a 30-minute conversation with Barbara Corcoran than in most college courses. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWe’d know, we did ’em both. The real estate mogul, \u003cem\u003eShark Tank\u003c/em\u003e mainstay, and host of the podcast \u003ca href=\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/business-unusual-with-barbara-corcoran/id1378685290?mt=2\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eBusiness Unusual\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003eanswered our Icebreaker questions with the same empathetic-but-no-BS attitude she displays on TV. Check out our interview below. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is the most frequent reason you’re “out” on a company on \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eShark Tank\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eA guy who doesn’t make eye contact with me or the women on the set. It happens more than you think. They want a guy as a partner and that’s where it ends—and you can tell right away when they stand on that set. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAre they just intimidated? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYes, but even when they’re not making eye contact because they’re intimidated I’m out right away. And I’m out for a good reason: because building a business takes a lot of on-the-spot pressure, fast-on-your-feet kind of thinking. You have to be able to perform under pressure. And I see right away this person is going to fold under pressure. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat is your secret skill?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI’m a helluva good tarot card reader. And I’ve lived long enough to see that most of what I’ve predicted has proved out. I’ve gotten very confident in my later years. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWait—how did you get into tarot cards? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOut of need, thinking on my feet. I went to a real estate conference at a young age and it was the first time I rented a booth, trying to hustle business straight from other brokers. Anyway, when I got to the conference there was nothing at the booth—I was mortified. So my associate and I ran out and bought tarot cards, and I started reading. And after about 40 minutes, there was a line a mile long for the tarot cards. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt was the best thing I ever thought of to promote business. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf you could do something that you don’t do because it’s bad for you, but you could do it without any repercussions—what would you do?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI would throw my phone off the Brooklyn Bridge and never read another text. Free myself. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou should do that.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYou know, I hate the word “should,” but I am going to do that now. What you just said. I’m going to do that this summer. I go to the beach, and I’m always on my phone when I never used to be. I had no TV, no radio, no phone, and I don’t think I’ve known that degree of relaxation probably for the last 15 years. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eYeah, I’m going to do that...I’m going to leave my phone in Manhattan. See how I survive. I will probably feel young again and relaxed. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/14/icebreakers-withbarbara-corcoran?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eso much more of the interview at this link\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F05%2F14%2Ficebreakers-withbarbara-corcoran-84ae\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make It Work logo\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers \u003ca href=\"https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereader-submitted questions\u003c/a\u003e about work in 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQ: \"I’m struggling with the possibility of leaving my company of almost 2.5 years. I’ve never felt supported or appreciated by management, and I don’t particularly like my colleagues. Do you have advice on how to have that conversation gracefully?\"—Ashley\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eA: \u003c/strong\u003eHi Ashley, I’m sorry that your experience at work has turned into a sour one. Let's talk next steps. You can have the notice conversation gracefully by letting your manager know as directly as possible (in person or over videochat) before submitting your resignation notice. You don't have to share with your manager why you’ve decided to leave, but be prepared to be asked the question by HR during your exit interview. End the news by saying that you are grateful for the experience and have learned skills that you will carry throughout your professional career.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eDon't believe me? Check out what another Sunday Edition reader submitted in response to a previous Make It Work post. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\"Hi, Kate. I just read your response to the person looking at changing jobs. I don’t disagree with what you wrote, but my experiences also include “how” I quit and change jobs. Even with the bad environments, I still left with good feelings, graciously, lots of warnings, and smooth transitions. Any scorched-earth actions will follow a person to future jobs. I still get calls and good references from past employers.\"—\u003c/em\u003eDarren Z.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOh! And please please give your employer a two-week notice, meaning 10 full business days, at minimum. Notices \u003cem\u003elonger\u003c/em\u003e than two weeks is an awesome look on you, too (side note: I would recommend a minimum of three weeks if you’re at the Director level or higher). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSomething bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Kate for advice here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F05%2F14%2Fmake-work-leave-company-gracefully\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nRevenge of the Retail Traders\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MAY 23:  An exterior view of Hertz Car Rental durin...\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MDc4L2RhaWx5X2xpZmVfaW5fbmV3X3lvcmtfY2kuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eCindy Ord/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBefore there was GameStop, there was Hertz.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLast June, a gang of Robinhood traders helped push the rental car’s stock up nearly 600% in less than a week, which was a curious thing to do considering the company had just filed for bankruptcy, was weighed down by nearly $19 billion in debt, and had roughly 700,000 cars parked with no one to drive them. Things were looking pretty bleak. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe Hertz traders were ridiculed as “\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2020-06-12/if-you-want-hertz-have-some-hertz?sref=KkPzpZvz\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enuts\u003c/a\u003e,” emblematic of the casino-type stock market that had emerged when the coronavirus wiped calendars clean. And they may very well have been nuts.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eBut they were vindicated\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis week, Hertz \u003ca href=\"https://news.yahoo.com/hertz-shareholders-line-8-recovery-115253916.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereached a deal\u003c/a\u003e with a couple private equity firms to take it out of bankruptcy. That deal is a stunning victory for shareholders.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt values the company at about $7 billion, and equity holders will receive up to $8/share. During the trading frenzy last June, Hertz topped out at $6.25 a share, which means if you were the fool who bought Hertz at its peak, you’d still have been undervaluing the company.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis arrangement is...highly unusual. Writing in Vanity Fair last June, former Wall Street banker William Cohan \u003ca href=\"https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2020/06/bankrupt-hertz-is-a-pandemic-zombie?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexplained\u003c/a\u003e what happens in typical corporate restructuring cases:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“What happens 99.9% of the time is that existing shareholders get wiped out and the creditors, most of which won’t get their money back, divide up what’s left of the carcass.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHe predicted “there will be no recovery for the shareholders. As in zero.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAt the time, most analysts agreed with Cohan. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut very few predicted how Hertz’s fortunes would change as the economy rocketed out of the pandemic. Blocked from traveling to many other countries, Americans are turning to road trips for summer 2021 vacations. Used cars accounted for more than a third of consumer price increases last month. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHertz has also gotten a little lucky—yes, we’re talking about the chip shortage. Car manufacturers have had to slow production of \u003cem\u003enew \u003c/em\u003ecars for lack of semiconductors, meaning rental car companies with fleets of used cars are in the right place at the right time.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eA full recovery for Hertz \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-12/once-doomed-hertz-rebounded-so-much-even-redditors-were-right?sref=KkPzpZvz\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eisn’t a slam dunk\u003c/a\u003e, Bloomberg writes. Revenue hasn’t returned to pre-pandemic levels and the chip shortage, while now an advantage, could turn into a liability if Hertz is forced to keep buying used cars, which are expensive and could degrade the quality of its fleet.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThroughout this rollercoaster of a pandemic-era stock market, it’s nearly impossible to tell which investors are smart, which ones are dumb, and which are just plain lucky. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F05%2F14%2Fhertz-shareholders-win-big-bankruptcy-deal\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
